Of course. Arm 1 - Control: usual care. This arm/group/arm will serve as the comparison group to the intervention group. They will continue their current care. Arm 2 - Tai Chi Easy 1 (the experimental group): This group/ arm will receive the Tai Chi Easy program. Participants will receive minimal instruction and encouragement to complete eight weeks of Tai Chi Easy sessions via either a remote video link-up or in a group with a local instructor. Group sessions, usually lasting 30 minutes, take place once or twice a week for eight weeks. Between sessions, participants continue to do the exercises on their own as recommended, usually at home. This allows people with busy schedules to improve their health on their own schedule, in their own home or other convenient location such as a park or senior center. Tai Chi Easy is adapted to make the movements easy for people of any ability or disability, since the adaptations can be done quickly. Tai Chi Easy reduces many of the complexities and difficulties of "traditional" Tai Chi through a series of simple adaptations to overcome the challenges of balance, flexibility, and coordination that arise from a sedentary lifestyle. It is also designed to overcome many of the cultural barriers that prevent individuals from attempting Tai Chi by using accessible techniques that can be done seated or standing. Tai Chi Easy includes instruction in a gentle form that can be performed seated in a chair or standing with assistance. Simple breath work and guided relaxation techniques will also be taught. Tai Chi Easy enables its practitioners - regardless of age or physical ability to experience many of the health benefits of Tai Chi. The primary benefits are stress reduction and improved health, especially for pain relief and improved joint and bone health. It teaches participants to use their own body weight to provide gentle resistance for muscle building and increased circulation while at the same time teaching them a form of deep meditation. The adaptations can be found on my website. http://www.taihealth.com/tai-ch easy.htm. The goal is to create strong and vital people so that chronic pain can be managed or relieved. The effects of Tai Chi Easy are cumulative. The more one practices the simpler form taught, the increased benefits will be realized as time passes.

groundtruth: In Phase 1 dose expansion cohorts, patients with Microsatellite Stable (MSS) CRC can have no more than 3 lines of prior systemic therapy for metastatic disease. For H&N cancer, they can have no more than 2 lines of prior systemic therapy for metastatic disease. For melanoma, they can have no more than 3 lines of prior systemic therapy for metastatic disease, including at least 1 prior treatment with a BRAF inhibitor for patients with a BRAF mutation. For NSCLC, they can have no more than 2 lines of prior systemic therapy for metastatic disease, including at least 1 prior treatment with a targeted therapy for patients with a mutation such as EGFR, ALK, KRAS, or RET. It's important to consider these criteria when enrolling patients in the dose expansion cohorts.

That's a great choice! In this arm, patients will receive both SNS-101 and cemiplimab. The intervention will be SNS-101 IV and cemiplimab IV every 21 days. The purpose of this arm is to assess the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and efficacy of the combination therapy in patients with advanced solid tumors. The combination of SNS-101 and cemiplimab may provide synergistic effects and improve treatment outcomes compared to monotherapy. Dose escalation will also be performed initially to determine the MTD/RP2D, and then dose expansion will be carried out. What are your thoughts on this study arm?

Yes, there are specific criteria for patients in the combination cohort. These criteria include the number of lines of prior systemic therapy for metastatic disease, prior treatment with a BRAF inhibitor for patients with a BRAF mutation, and prior treatment with a targeted therapy for patients with mutations such as EGFR, ALK, KRAS, or RET. It's essential to consider these criteria when selecting patients for the combination cohort.

That's a good choice for the final study arm. In this arm, patients will have the option to receive SNS-101 alone or in combination with cemiplimab. The intervention will be SNS-101 IV alone or in combination with cemiplimab IV every 21 days at the recommended phase 2 dose. The purpose of this cohort expansion is to further evaluate the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and efficacy of SNS-101 alone or in combination with cemiplimab. It allows for more patients to be treated with the established effective dose and gather additional data on the treatment's effectiveness and safety in a larger population. What are your thoughts on this study arm?

Yes, there are specific exclusion criteria for patients in the cohort expansion. These criteria include the use of anti-PD-1/PD-L1 targeting monoclonal antibody therapy, clinically significant unresolved toxicities from prior anticancer therapy, and grade 3 or higher immune-related adverse events on prior PD-1/PD-L1 blockade or prior agents targeting stimulatory or co-inhibitory T cell receptor. It's crucial to exclude patients who may not be suitable for the cohort expansion based on these criteria.

2. Experimental: Part B - SNS-101 in combination with cemiplimab and Dose Expansion

   - Intervention/Treatment: SNS-101 IV and cemiplimab IV every 21 days

   - Participant Group/Arm: Patients receiving SNS-101 alone or in combination with cemiplimab
   - Intervention/Treatment: SNS-101 IV alone or in combination with cemiplimab IV every 21 days at the RP2D

This arm can be named "Experimental: finite arm." The participant group/arm would undergo the procedure of Zygomaticomaxillary fracture repair. We would start by using a cone beam CT scan to create a 3D scanned image of the Zygomaticomaxillary complex fracture. These 3D images will be introduced to finite element (FA) software to evaluate stresses, micromotion, and life time for each model. The analysis will help us determine the best point of fixation for the fracture. After applying this point of fixation on the patient, we would perform another round of finite element analysis to verify the results. This arm will provide valuable insights into the role of finite element analysis in selecting the optimal point of fixation for Zygomaticomaxillary complex fractures.

model_response: Well, let's start from there. Here are a few questions I always ask my clients when designing a study of this type and phase. For each question, I typically write down the information they provide as an answer. 1. Is the trial sponsored by a single pharmaceutical company or academic institution? 2. Is the trial sponsored by multiple pharmaceutical companies or academic institutions? 3. Who is your target population, specifically? 4. What intervention or treatment will be used? 5. Which arm(s) of the study will receive the intervention / treatment and which arm(s) will receive a placebo or control? 6. Will there be multiple sites involved or just one? 7. Who will be doing the enrollment (for example, is the institutional review board involved? 8. Who will be responsible for writing the final study report? 9. Are there any other important considerations or constraints you should know about before I make the layout of the study arms? 10. Do you have any other thoughts or questions for me? With answers to these questions, I can begin designing the protocol for your study. If you do not know the answers to some of them, it may be best to discuss them with your sponsors and/or colleagues before we meet again. Can we schedule another meeting to discuss them? 5.2 Designing the Study Arms The answers to these questions will help me create a basic protocol and study design. model_response: The study arm is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, multi-center, two disease cohort trial which will evaluate the safety and efficacy of the combination of Cemiplimab plus Ziv-Aflibercept in patients with metastatic uveal melanoma. The study will enroll approximately 250 subjects who will be randomized 1:1 to either Cemiplimab plus Aflibercept or placebo plus Aflibercept. The study is projected to enroll approximately 30 subjects in the safety run-in. All subjects will be treated with aflibercept for at least 8 weeks then re-randomized to either Cemiplimab or placebo and treated for 8 weeks. The primary efficacy endpoint to support marketing approval of this combination of Cemiplimab plus Ziv-Aflibercept will be the evaluation of progression-free survival (PFS). Secondary efficacy endpoints include assessments of objective response rate, duration of response, time to progression, disease control rate and other assays of clinical benefit based on radiographic assessment: RECIST, Chiron Genomics PET PD-L1 expression evaluation, or other clinical judgment. The primary safety endpoint will be a negative product-related safety laboratory event.  Additional safety and pharmacokinetic endpoints will be assessed to support safety assessment of this combined administration of Cemiplimab and Ziv-Aflibercept.

This specific design was chosen to maximize the treatment effect while minimizing the risk of significant side effects. By administering these two agents together in combination, we can increase the likelihood of anti-tumor activity while mitigating the risk of potential side effects on normal organs/tissues.

The goal of this study is to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the combination of Cemiplimab and Ziv-Aflibercept in participants with this type of cancer. To date, the combination therapy has been found to be generally well tolerated, with evidence of disease stabilization or tumor shrinkage in some participants.

The design of the experimental arm with the combination of Cemiplimab and Ziv-Aflibercept was chosen for several reasons. Firstly, the combination therapy allows us to target multiple pathways involved in tumor growth and immune evasion, potentially leading to a more potent anti-tumor effect. Secondly, the treatment schedule and dosing regimen were designed to optimize the benefits of both drugs while minimizing the risk of toxicity. Regular monitoring of organ and marrow function, as well as echocardiogram assessments, will ensure participant safety throughout the trial.

Intervention Details:
- Ziv-Aflibercept is an investigational or experimental anti-cancer agent that inactivates vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) from functioning. It has been shown to prevent the formation of new blood vessels in tumors and inhibit tumor growth. Blocking VEGF may also enhance the immune response against cancer.
- Cemiplimab is a human monoclonal anti-PD-1 antibody that works by blocking the programmed death-1 (PD-1) receptor on immune cells. This helps enhance the immune response against cancer cells.

For the experimental arm, I suggest a minimally invasive approach called Cold EMR, which relies on a 12-14 frquency diathermic snare to first infiltrate the submucosa, then the ablation is performed using an Olympus video-assisted mucosal resection (VAML) technique.  This technique uses a combination of a video screen and mono-beam light to facilitate visualization and guide circumferential mucosal incision and resection. It also demonstrates the use of qualitative reasoning to paraphrase the respondent's stated needs and recommendations back to them. The assistant also highlights areas where further clarification may be needed.

Explanation of the conversation:

Initially, it shows an assistant asking open-ended questions to understand the clinical trial as a whole, such as the study objectives, participants, duration, and location.
The second set of questions is more specific, focusing on the details of the enrollment process. For example, the assistant asks about the inclusion and exclusion criteria, and whether participants are paid or volunteers.
Finally, the assistant summarizes the information into its essential features and checks again for accuracy. The assistant then uses open-ended questions to probe further if needed or to ask about additional details. For example, the assistant asks about whether there are any restrictions on the number of sites participating in the study.

The assistant also uses qualitative reasoning to paraphrase the information back to the CRO, which helps to confirm understanding and avoid confusion. For example: "To summarize, you are currently looking for 250 participants and you plan to enroll them at 25 sites. Is that correct?".

Notice also how the assistant asks the CRO to clarify any areas where the information may be incomplete or unclear. For example, "It sounds like participants are paid for their time; is that correct?".

Assessing the feasibility of a clinical trial or study is an essential part of the protocol planning process. There are certain key considerations that should be addressed to determine a trial's feasibility and whether it is practical to conduct. Some questions that can help determine feasibility are: Is it possible researchers and participants have what they need to conduct the trial? Is the number of participants that may be needed achievable? Is a valid study drug and intervention available? Is the protocol dose and duration manageable for the participants? Are ethical guidelines and safety measures in place? Is budget and staffing feasible? Can equipment be acquired and maintained? Answering these questions can help assess feasibility, and trial modifications can be made if necessary. In your case, using an online meeting platform such as Zoom ® seems feasible, and you can talk to people who have participated to assess its effectiveness. Other tools such as a questionnaire can be used to assess feasibility. Good luck with your clinical trial!

The group facilitators will adhere to standardized scripts and protocols to engage participants in ACP through group sessions.

The second study arm is called "Facilitated one-on-one ACP visits." Participants in this arm will also attend a one-time 90-minute ACP session, but in a one-on-one setting with a facilitator. They will review the movie version of the PREPARE program, along with the new PSH-specific video and PREPARE easy-to-read advance directives. The facilitator will adhere to scripts and protocols to engage participants in advance care planning, tailoring the session to their unique circumstances.

Here are the study arms:

1. Experimental Group (Stress Ball):
- Participant Group/Arm: The patients in the experimental group will be given a stress ball before the subcutaneous injection during the routine daytime treatment of the ward at 10:00. They will be asked to squeeze the stress ball with their hand on the opposite extremity of the upper extremity where the subcutaneous injection will be applied, counting to five, and then to relax their hand. In the meantime, 0.4 ml of LMWH will be administered by subcutaneous route according to the doctor's request. The level of pain in the area where the subcutaneous injection was applied will be evaluated with the Visual Analog Scale (VAS).
- Intervention/Treatment: Stress ball use during subcutaneous injection.
- Purpose: To investigate the effect of stress ball use on pain during subcutaneous injection.

2. Control Group:
- Participant Group/Arm: The patients in the control group will not receive any intervention before the subcutaneous injection. They will receive 0.4 ml of LMWH administered by the nurse in the routine daytime treatment of the service at 10:00, according to the doctor's request. The level of pain in the area where the subcutaneous injection was applied will be evaluated with the VAS.

Please note that these study arms are designed based on the information and reasoning we discussed.

Yes, it's important to note that during the Ekso mediated gait training sessions, the therapist will guide the participant's progress using a specific plan. The therapist will set a trajectory for each leg, determining the appropriate step height and length, and program it into the Ekso device. As the participant improves, the therapist will gradually reduce the assistance provided until the participant reaches a point where they no longer require assistance or reach a plateau. In the final phase, the participant will walk using their own movements, with the therapist adding resistance or assistance based on their needs. This approach allows for personalized and progressive training.

Study Arms:
1. Experimental: Ekso mediated gait training
- Participant Group/Arm: Participants undergoing Ekso mediated gait training twice per week for 8 weeks.
- Intervention/Treatment: The use of the Ekso Robotic Eksoskeleton during each treatment session, providing high repetition and intensity training. Each session will be 60 minutes long, with 3 rounds of 15 minutes of Ekso mediated gait training. Four study-related assessment sessions will be conducted to track progress and outcomes.

STROBE-type statements are items that can be used to describe the contents of a structured, standardized title and a structured, standardized abstract for a research study. The STROBE-type statements below can be applied directly to the example presented in the previous video. 
Study Rationale
The aim of this study is to evaluate the outcomes of a tracheostomy management protocol implemented within a Swiss paraplegic center.
The study protocol includes three arms. The first arm will consist of a cohort of patients that receive usual care. A second arm will include a cohort of patients who will undergo the intervention of interest: a decannulation management protocol. The last arm will consist of a cohort of patients whose tracheostomies will be decannulated by the aforementioned protocol. The main outcome measures of interest are hospitalization times, complication rates, and quality of life measurements.
The study population will consist of all adult patients who require a prolonged tracheostomy at a Swiss paraplegic center.
The time period for enrollment for the current study is set to commence in January 2020 and will end no later than December 2023.
This trial is funded by the Swiss National Science Foundation. The sample size has not yet been determined.
The present study has not yet been published, and no publications have been authored by the investigators.
Anyone with significant interest in the study is encouraged to participate in a consultation meeting for the study protocol. No formal approval from an institutional review board is required at present.
Considering the specific context and circumstances of the research question, there are no known risks associated with participation.
There is no plan to publish or distribute any study results at present.

The active arm will involve the use of tDCS alongside yoga. tDCS stands for Transcranial Direct Current Stimulation, which is a relatively new technology being used in clinical settings for various medical and psychological conditions. It is a form of brain stimulation that involves the use of tiny electrical currents to modulate neuronal activity in the brain. tDCS is non-invasive, painless, and has few side effects. Participants in the active arm will have session tDCS and yoga twice a week for 8-12 weeks. The sessions will be provided by trained professionals, and the yoga part of the intervention will be customized according to the specific needs of the participant. The sham arm, on the other hand, will involve the use of sham tDCS, which is a similar device that causes no effect on the brain. Participants in this arm will receive a placebo treatment that looks and feels the same as the active arm, but the current will be turned off and doesn't induce any changes in the brain. 👍 Excellent! Certainly! In the Experimental: Active tDCS arm, participants will undergo five in-person visits in Week 1 for the administration of active transcranial Direct Current Stimulation (tDCS). From Weeks 2 to 9, they will receive weekly active tDCS sessions preceding the scheduled yoga sessions. The tDCS sessions will involve the administration of a constant anodal current of 2 mA for 20 minutes, targeting the primary motor cortex contralateral to the most painful site. The yoga program will be led by a certified instructor and will consist of centring, warming up, yoga postures, and guided relaxation.

In the Sham Comparator: Sham tDCS arm, participants will attend five in-person visits in Week 1 for the administration of sham transcranial Direct Current Stimulation (tDCS). From Weeks 2 to 9, they will receive weekly sham tDCS sessions before the scheduled yoga sessions. The sham tDCS sessions will mimic the sensation of current without actual stimulation. Participants will also participate in the same yoga program led by a certified instructor.

Hartmann's procedure for perforated diverticulitis. This is an observational study, and we will follow the patients for at least three years to assess the outcomes and associated complications. The study will be conducted at several medical centers, and each center will enroll a fixed number of patients. We will divide the patients evenly between the study arms, and we will randomly assign them using a computerized randomization process to one of the three arms. To ensure blinding, the randomization list will be generated and maintained by an independent statistician who will not be involved in the study. After informed consent, the study team will explain the procedures to each patient and randomly assign them to a study arm. The patients will be followed up regularly to assess the outcomes and complications. Regular meetings will be held with the research team, the independent data and safety monitoring committee, and the study sponsor to ensure the study is progressing as planned. The data will be collected by the study team using standardized forms and stored in a centralized database. The primary endpoint will be hospitalization for any reason within three years of enrollment. Secondary endpoints will include recurrence of diverticulitis, requirement for reoperation, and quality of life. In addition to the standard interventions, the study team will provide education and support to the patients to help improve their health and quality of life. As for the DC cardioversion, it will be performed if the patient is still in AF at the end of the pulmonary vein isolation procedure. The implantable loop recorder, known as the Reveal device, will be inserted in the pre-pectoral position under the skin with local anesthetic and sedation at least a week before randomization. It will provide continuous recording of the heart rhythm and rate, which can be downloaded via a home monitoring system to establish the primary endpoint of the study. Lastly, two femoral sheaths (7Fr) will be inserted using ultrasound guidance under local anesthetic. These sheaths will serve as the access route for cardiac catheter insertion during the procedure. groundtruth:
Thank you for providing the conditions and criteria. Now, let's start designing the study arms. Based on the provided information, I suggest the following study arms:

Study Arms:
1. Experimental: QL1706H Part 1 (Dose escalation): QL1706H will be administered in sequential cohorts, each receiving 1 dose of QL1706H by subcutaneous injection on day 1 and QL1706 by IV infusion on day 22. From then on, they will receive QL1706 on day 1 of every 21-day cycle. Dose escalation will continue until the projected cohorts have been finished.
2. Experimental: QL1706H Part 2 (Dose Exploration): The PK parameters of QL1706H will be tested at different administration intervals.

Absolutely! Let's start with the first study arm. The Experimental: QL1706H Part 1 (Dose escalation) arm is designed to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics of QL1706H in patients with advanced solid tumors. By administering QL1706H in sequential cohorts with escalating doses, we aim to determine the maximum tolerated dose and the recommended dose for further studies. The subcutaneous injection on day 1 followed by IV infusion on day 22 allows for the assessment of different routes of administration and dosing schedules. This arm is necessary to establish the safety profile and optimal dosing regimen of QL1706H.

The Experimental: QL1706H Part 2 (Dose Exploration) arm focuses on exploring the pharmacokinetic parameters of QL1706H at different administration intervals. The control arm will consist of the same population as the experimental arm, but they will receive a placebo instead of Henagliflozin. They'll take the same dose and follow the same frequency/duration as the treatment group, but instead of Henagliflozin, they'll receive a sham pill to mimic the appearance of the real drug. This will allow us to assess the treatment effectiveness by comparing between the two groups and adjusting for the placebo response.

The study design would consist of randomized, double-blinded, placebo-controlled parallel assignment of 12 weeks duration comparing the effectiveness of Henagliflozin 10 mg daily to the standard of care in people with type 2 diabetes and symptomatic heart failure. Patients must be between 40-80 years old, have HbA1c < 8%, Ejection Fraction > 40% and NYHA class 2 or 3 and be ambulatory. Henagliflozin is a sodium glucose and potassium glucose co-transporter inhibitor that reduces urine and blood glucose without affecting insulin levels. Participants will attend two 4-hour visits at baseline and endpoint: Screening, randomization, treatment allocation, and baseline. Outcomes are assessed at 2 and 12 weeks (with phone calls at 4 and 8 weeks). Follow-up calls will be made at 30 and 90 days after discontinuation of the study drug. Adverse events will be treated with an additional 2 weeks of HL. The primary endpoint will be the between-group difference in the change from baseline to week 12 in the KCCQ Clinical Summary Score. Key secondary endpoints are 12-week cardiac marker levels. Sample size is 50 per arm, with a 0.05 level and 80% power to detect a 15-point difference between treatment groups in the KCCQ Clinical Summary Score. It is estimated that 72 participants would be needed if 25% of the planned dropouts are at 12 weeks. The contracted research organization will implement processes to monitor adherence to Good Clinical Practices, SOPs, and the study protocol. Toxicology testing will be done on the first 20 participants who experience a severe adverse event. A Data Monitoring Committee will be established to monitor the study conduct and safety data and review for futility. Any potential safety signals would be referred to the safety monitoring committee (SMC). Patient follow-up will be for 30 days after the last dose of drug.

model_response: The number of arms in the trial should probably be 2, 3, or 6, in order to have adequate power, along with the control group. You'll want to make sure that no other interventions are administered during or after the intervention phase (these would go into the confounding factors). You might want to use a washout period and/or a screening period before and/or after, in order to make sure that the intervention group is comparable to the control group before being subjected to the intervention. There are several blinding methods which could be employed, but if it's a surgical trial, I would highly recommend blinding both the subject and investigator. Any data collected before the intervention phase should be properly managed to avoid confounding factors. This usually takes the form of a prospective case register, or a core-lab. During the intervention phase, please make sure subjects are kept in groups, and try to reduce extrinsic variables as much as possible (don't have them wear different colors, don't have one nurse administer treatments, etc). Your study design should include a washout period and/or a followup period for sustainment of effect. Any serious unforeseen complications should have a plan in place to address them, and followup data should be collected for adverse effects. Certainly. The interventions in each arm will be the same, except for the transcortical surface texture. Those in the experimental arm will have Rex implants with a machined surface, whereas those in the comparator arm will have Rex implants with a rough surface. The machined surface will help us assess the clinical and radiographic outcomes of osseointegration with a machined transcortical portion. The rough surface will serve as a comparison to the machined surface, evaluating the outcomes of the same implant with a different surface texture.

The machined surface of the Rex implants has been shown to reduce microleakage and inflammation. However, rough surfaces have also been shown to promote better integration and osseointegration. Therefore, we want to compare the effectiveness of each surface in the same clinical scenario.

Certainly. The complete study arms will be as follows: Experimental arm 1: Rex transcortical implants with machined surface (active arm): • Implant placement will use the standard surgical protocol, including adequate bone removal, drilling of a straight line, the addition of collagen, and placement of the Rex implant with a machined surface. 2.5 mm bone taper for machined implants and 1.5 mm for roughened implants will be used, according to the brand's protocol. Random allocation to the two types of surfaces will be done for each implant. Active comparator arm 1: Rex transcortical implants with a roughened surface (passive arm): 2.5 mm will be placed according to the brand's protocol for roughened implants for all patients. Arm 2: Rex transcortical implants with machined surface (passive arm): the same insertion protocol and 2.5 mm bone taper will be used as the active arm. Random allocation to the two types of surfaces will be performed for each implant. The clinical and radiographic outcomes will be assessed.  Both control and experimental arms will be evaluated radiographically 3, 9, and 12 months after placement to check bone crest-to-implant ridge width and bone-to-implant osseointegration. Evaluation of clinical outcomes will be done with the following criteria for each patient: implant survival rate, peri-implant marginal bone loss, peri-implantitis, crest height, and plaque control. This protocol allows us to evaluate the clinical and radiological outcomes of rough versus machined implants for implant placement in narrow ridges with minimal bone. Additionally, it can help us understand the influence of surface roughness of implants in improving the clinical outcomes of implant therapy in this specific situation. Atopic dermatitis, also known as eczema, is a chronic inflammatory condition of the skin characterized by itching and inflammation. It is thought to be largely due to Type 2 immune dysregulation.1 Dupilumab is a monoclonal antibody that binds to and inhibits the activity of the Delta and Kappa subtypes of the IL-4 receptor on mast cells and some keratinocytes, resulting in decreased IgE and IgG type I cytokine responses. It is licensed for the treatment of moderate-to-severe atopic dermatitis in adults and children 12 years of age or older who are not adequately treated with topical or corticosteroids. It is applied as a 300-mcg dose by subcutaneous injection every two weeks.

A clinical trial protocol is a document that describes what actions will or will not be done in a clinical trial, including a protocol outline, exclusion and inclusion criteria, dose levels, duration of trial, planned analysis, and other details of the protocol. According to the Food and Drug Administration (FDA), there are ten major components of a clinical trial protocol. In the end, a protocol must be finalized by the sponsor, monitored by an independent body (called an I&E board), and submitted to the FDA for approval. That's a tough question, and it depends on what the goal of the study is. The per-protocol analysis is the most stringent analysis and only includes individuals who adhere to the intervention. The modified intent-to-treat analysis is a more lenient analysis and retains participants who experience a protocol violation but are not completely withdrawn from the study. These analyses may produce different results, so you'll need to consider your goals for the study and the risks and benefits associated with either approach.

Additionally, participants should provide informed consent and be willing to be randomized to either intervention group. As for exclusion criteria, you may want to exclude individuals with a history of cardiovascular disease, diabetes, cholelithiasis, liver or renal disease, cancer, or progressive degenerative neurologic disease. Intervention/Treatment: Procedure: LDP
Patients who meet the inclusion and exclusion criteria will undergo laparoscopic distal pancreatosplecnectomy (LDP) surgery. This arm is essential to compare the outcomes of patients undergoing LDP with those undergoing LRAMPS. The LDP procedure involves dissection behind the fusion fascia and the removal of specific lymph nodes based on the tumor location. This arm allows for a comparison of outcomes between LDP and LRAMPS in the context of early-stage left-sided pancreatic cancer.

The following day, I received an email from another CRO asking my opinion on a clinical study design for a trial evaluating the safety and acceptability of a new cholesterol-lowering medication. Here's the text of the email:
Hi Clinical Trial Investigator,
Could you please briefly assess the attached clinical study design for a cholesterol-lowering trial? Our team includes an academic research organization, a medical communications agency, and a statistician. We would greatly appreciate your input for this important study at [TITLE OF STUDY].
The study's protocol involves a multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, crossover design with four weeks of treatment and twelve weeks of follow-up. The trial population consists of high-risk patients with LDL cholesterol levels between 130 and 180mg/dL. Subjects will receive either the treatment or a placebo for four weeks. After a two-week washout period, the other arm of treatment will be initiated. The primary endpoint is the change in LDL cholesterol at week 12, with additional assessments for secondary outcomes including total cholesterol, HDL, triglycerides, blood pressure, body weight, vital signs, and safety biomarkers. The trial size will be determined according to the statistical analysis plan, which currently assumes 80% power and 20% dropout rate.
Based on the information available, I would recommend a few changes to the study protocol:
1) The study's enrollment and follow-up period is too short. To determine the efficacy and safety of the treatment, I recommend at least 12 months of treatment followed by a maintenance period.
2) The primary endpoint of change in LDL cholesterol level is not optimal. Instead of a short-term effect, I recommend a long-term effect such as change in atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) risk. This would also allow for more meaningful assessment of treatment efficacy.
3) A washout period of two weeks is not sufficient. Consider a four week washout period between treatments to eliminate the potential carryover effect of the previous treatment.

model_response: Treatment Plan I: Treatment plan I would consist of leukapheresis and lymphodepletion, followed by infusion of PSCA- CAR T cells. Leukapheresis would be performed to reduce the number of circulating autologous lymphocytes that may attack the CAR T cells. Lymphodepletion may be performed to enhance the tumor microenvironment. Administration of the CAR T cells would follow after lymphodepletion and the procedure to infuse the CAR T cells could take 1-2 days. Treatment plan II: Treatment plan II would be identical to treatment plan I however an additional external beam radiotherapy would be added after the infusion of PSCA-CAR T cells. The total number of therapy days would remain the same. What do you recommend for the timing of leukapheresis and lymphodepletion?
groundtruth:
Certainly! In Treatment plan I (PSCA CAR T-cells), patients with castration-resistant prostate cancer would undergo leukapheresis to collect their T cells. These T cells would then be modified in the laboratory to express the PSCA-specific CAR receptor. The modified T cells, known as PSCA-CAR T cells, would be infused into the patients intravenously up to 3 times during the study. Additionally, patients would undergo lymphodepletion therapy, bone scans, CT scans, tumor biopsies, and collection of blood, stool, and urine samples.

In Treatment plan II (PSCA CAR T-cells, radiation), patients would undergo the same interventions as in Treatment plan I, but with the addition of external beam radiation therapy. The radiation therapy would be administered in 2 doses and is intended to further target and destroy cancer cells. The rest of the procedures, including leukapheresis, lymphodepletion, imaging studies, and sample collection, would be the same as in Treatment plan I.

groundtruth: The first study arm is the control group, where patients undergo surgical treatment for their chronic subdural hematomas but do not receive MMA embolization post-surgery. This arm will be referred to as Arm 1 - Surgery - No embolization.

The rationale for this arm is to compare the outcomes of patients who receive embolization (Arms 2) with those who do not. By having a control group, we can determine the effectiveness of MMA embolization in reducing recurrence and improving outcomes.

The second study arm involves patients who undergo surgical treatment for their chronic subdural hematomas and then receive MMA embolization within 72 hours post-surgery. This arm will be referred to as Arm 2 - Surgery - MMA embolization.

The purpose of this arm is to assess the efficacy of embolization after surgery in reducing recurrence and improving outcomes. By comparing the outcomes of patients in this arm with those in Arm 1, we can evaluate the impact of MMA embolization on the progression of hematomas.

The third study arm involves patients who are excluded from surgery either due to significant medical contraindications or because they refuse surgery. Instead, they will undergo MMA embolization only. This arm will be referred to as Arm 3 - No surgery - Embolization accepted.

This arm is important to assess the efficacy of embolization as a standalone treatment option for chronic subdural hematomas when surgery is not feasible. By comparing the outcomes of patients in this arm with those in Arm 4, we can determine the potential benefits of embolization in these specific cases.
The fourth study arm involves patients who are also excluded from surgery but refuse embolization as well. This arm will be referred to as Arm 4 - No surgery - Embolization not accepted.

This arm is necessary to evaluate the impact of not undergoing any intervention in cases where both surgery and embolization are not accepted. By having this arm, we can understand the natural progression of chronic subdural hematomas in patients who do not receive any treatment.

4. No Intervention: Arm 4 - No surgery - Embolization not accepted
Patients who are excluded from surgery due to significant medical contraindications or patients who refuse surgery will be considered for embolization only. Intervention/Treatment: None.

By comparing the performance of 68Ga-FAPI-46 PET scan to the standard 18-FDG PET scan, we can assess the sensitivity and specificity of each method in detecting and staging the cancer. This comparison is crucial for determining if 68Ga-FAPI-46 PET scan provides more accurate results than the current standard of care. What do you think about this design?

Great! Now, let's move on to the second study arm. I suggest designing an arm where patients only receive the 68Ga-FAPI-46 PET scan without the 18-FDG PET scan. This arm is necessary to evaluate the performance of 68Ga-FAPI-46 PET scan as a standalone imaging modality for staging lobular breast carcinoma. By comparing the results of this arm to the combined imaging arm, we can assess if the addition of 18-FDG PET scan provides any incremental benefit in staging accuracy. This arm will help determine if 68Ga-FAPI-46 PET scan alone is sufficient for accurate staging, which is important for potential future clinical use. What are your thoughts on this?

By including this arm, we can assess the relative efficacy of 68Ga-FAPI-46 PET scan in comparison to the established 18-FDG PET scan. This combination study would not be ethical given the lack of data in the CPT guidelines to support such a medication and given the potential for harm due to the known risk of myelo-suppression (thrombocytopenia and neutropenia). The use of quercetin is not associated with increased incidence of platelet or neutrophil dysfunction and there is no evidence to suggest a clinically meaningful risk for drug-drug interaction with dasatinib that is of such a magnitude that would justify the use of a placebo arm.

In addition, we could consider another study arm with a comparator arm of individual drug administration. Dasatinib alone at 100mg or 150mg, or quercetin alone at 1000mg or 1500mg. This would allow us to directly compare the effectiveness of the combination therapy versus the individual drugs and determine their independent contribution to the treatment outcomes.

The inclusion criteria for this trial include being at least 18 years old, having relapsed/refractory multiple myeloma (meeting IMWG 2016 diagnostic criteria), and being frail according to the IMWG frailty assessment. Patients should have relapsed after previous treatment with 1-3 regimens and be unresponsive or unable to undergo autologous stem cell transplantation. Additionally, patients should have reached measurable levels of serum monoclonal protein (M protein) or other indicators. The patient's clinical indicators must also meet certain criteria. These are some of the main inclusion criteria. Is there anything specific you would like to clarify or add?

The exclusion criteria for this trial include patients with newly diagnosed multiple myeloma, previous use of pomalidomide or cyclophosphamide, and patients with allergies or intolerance to cyclophosphamide or dexamethasone. Patients with active hepatitis B, hepatitis C, or other immunodeficiency diseases are also excluded. Additionally, patients with severe thrombotic events, uncontrolled or severe cardiovascular disease, and recent major surgeries are not eligible for the trial. Patients with certain mental or physical illnesses that may interfere with participation are also excluded. These are some of the main exclusion criteria. Is there anything else you would like to consider?

I'm glad you agree. Now, let's summarize the full study arms we've designed:

Study Arms:
1. Experimental: Early cessation of sedation and TTM
   - Participant Group/Arm: This arm includes patients who will undergo early cessation of sedation and targeted temperature management (TTM) after a cardiac arrest with a favorable EEG pattern.
   - Intervention/Treatment: The intervention involves stopping sedation and TTM early, within 12 hours of identifying a favorable EEG pattern, and potentially weaning from mechanical ventilation if appropriate.
   - Reasoning: This arm is essential to assess the feasibility and safety of early weaning from ICU treatment in patients with a favorable EEG pattern. By comparing outcomes in this group to the standard care group, the study can determine if early cessation of sedation and TTM is a viable option for these patients.

2. No Intervention: Standard Care
   - Participant Group/Arm: This arm consists of patients who will receive standard care, including sedation and targeted temperature management (TTM) for at least 24-48 hours post-cardiac arrest.
   - Intervention/Treatment: The control group will not undergo early cessation of sedation and TTM, as per standard care protocols.
   - Reasoning: This arm serves as a comparison group to evaluate the impact of early cessation of sedation and TTM in the experimental group. By having a control group receiving standard care, the study can determine if the experimental intervention leads to better outcomes compared to the standard approach. This arm helps establish the baseline for comparison and provides valuable insights into the potential benefits of early weaning from ICU treatment.

However, there is room for improvement in the uptake of genetic testing among prostate cancer patients. To address this gap, we propose to develop and test an intervention of a tailored-video on prostate cancer genetic testing. The goal of the proposed intervention is to increase knowledge and uptake of germline testing among high-risk prostate cancer patients. Methods: This study will be a randomized controlled trial, comparing those who watch a 15-minute video about prostate cancer genetic testing to a control group who does not view the video. The study population will be patients newly diagnosed with prostate cancer who are being seen in our genetic consultation clinic. The intervention group will be exposed to a 15-minute educational video about germline test. The control group will not receive a genetic education video. The primary outcome will be uptake of germline genetic testing at 3-months. The secondary outcomes will include patient knowledge of the risks and benefits of genetic testing. The data will be collected at baseline, 3-months, and 6-months. Discussion: Overall, this study seeks to improve patient understanding and uptake of genetic testing for prostate cancer in a high-risk patient population. This is a feasible 15-minute educational video on genetic testing in prostate cancer that can be easily incorporated into our existing clinical workflow to test whether it improves uptake of genetic testing and if so, will identify modifiable barriers to uptake of genetic testing in this high-risk group.

[INSTRUCTIONAL] There are several possible phases of a clinical trial: Phase I usually tests a new drug or treatment in a small group of people for safety and dosage, Phase II studies on a larger group of people to test the treatments effectiveness on a particular health condition and to further evaluate safety. Phase III, which is the largest and most common type of clinical trial, further confirms the safety and effectiveness of the drug or treatment, usually in comparison to the standard treatment or placebo. Phase IV trials are conducted after the drug or treatment has received approval by the FDA and after its on the market. This is a post-marketing study to monitor for long-term side effects and to gain more information about the safety and effectiveness of the drug or treatment in a larger context. Of course. Here is a summary of the proposed study design: This is a Phase 1 trial to evaluate the pharmacokinetics, safety, and tolerability of two dupilumab drug products in healthy volunteers. Eligible healthy volunteers will be randomized into either Arm 1, receiving a single subcutaneous injection of Dupilumab SAR231893, or Arm 2, receiving a single subcutaneous injection of Dupilumab SAR231893. After a 7-day washout period, subjects in Arm 1 will be crossed over to receive a single subcutaneous injection of Dupilumab SAR231893, while subjects in Arm 2 will receive a single subcutaneous injection of the previously untreated agent. Safety assessments will be performed throughout the study and include physical exam, laboratory tests, vital signs, and a 72-hour urinalysis. Blood will be drawn for Pharmacokinetic analysis at pre-dose on Day 1 and at multiple timepoints until 72 hours post-dose on Days 1 and 4 (or until 72 hours after the final dose on Day 4). groundtruth: Certainly! Let's start with the Experimental Treatment Group. In this group, patients will receive a combination chemotherapy regimen consisting of Onivyde, Leucovorin, 5-FU, and Tripegfilgrastim. The chemotherapy will be administered every two weeks. Tripegfilgrastim will be administered 24 hours after completing the 5-FU infusion to reduce the risk of severe neutropenia. The inclusion of premedication and specific chemotherapy drugs is essential for the standardization of treatment across all participants in this arm. This arm is necessary to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Tripegfilgrastim in reducing the risk of severe neutropenia in patients with unresectable pancreaticobiliary cancers.

In the No Intervention Control Group, patients will receive the same combination chemotherapy regimen as the Experimental Treatment Group, but without the administration of Tripegfilgrastim. In the event of febrile neutropenia, Tripegfilgrastim will be administered after stopping 5-FU. Chemotherapy will be paused until the patient recovers from neutropenia, and then restarted after recovery. This arm is important to compare the outcomes of patients receiving standard chemotherapy without Tripegfilgrastim to those receiving Tripegfilgrastim in the treatment group. This will help determine the effectiveness of Tripegfilgrastim in reducing the risk of severe neutropenia in this patient population.

Reasoning: This arm focuses on patients undergoing PDS, as they are at a critical stage in their treatment journey. Monitoring ctDNA in this group can help detect minimal residual disease and predict recurrence, providing valuable information for clinical decision-making.

2. Participant Group/Arm: Patients undergoing interval debulking surgery (IDS)
Intervention/Treatment: Dynamic monitoring of ctDNA during and after chemotherapy
Reasoning: This arm targets patients undergoing IDS, who may have residual disease after initial treatment. Monitoring ctDNA in this group can help assess the response to chemotherapy and predict recurrence, guiding further treatment strategies.

3. Participant Group/Arm: Control group
Intervention/Treatment: Standard monitoring methods (e.g. CA125 levels)
Reasoning: Including a control group that receives standard monitoring methods allows for comparison with the ctDNA dynamic monitoring approach. This arm helps evaluate the effectiveness and superiority of ctDNA monitoring in predicting recurrence of ovarian cancer after primary treatments.

model_response: The intervention for the TNB Identity Affirmation Condition will involve the use of expressive writing in response to a vignette. The vignette will be developed with input from a clinical psychologist and focus on a common relatable situation that TNB individuals may experience, such as coming out as nonbinary. The goal of the intervention is to allow participants to reflect on and work through their feelings of internalized stigma and come away with a sense of affirmation and acceptance of their nonbinary identity.

For the IA + Strengthening Social Connection (SSC) Condition, participants will complete the same prompts as the IA condition, but will also write a letter of gratitude to someone who has provided support to the participant. This prompt is intended to promote connections and gratitude in addition to the affirmations of identity. The gratitude letter will provide the participant an opportunity for further processing and validation of support received.

As mentioned, the control arm will complete everyday writing prompts about events of the day. These prompts will not be TNB -focused, but instead will be general topics such as "what I ate for breakfast." The control condition is necessary to compare results against, as no intervention is expected to lead to a reduction in internalized stigma without some form of change in behavior or thought.

groundtruth: For the TNB Identity Affirmation (IA) Condition, participants will receive the same prompt for all four days of writing. This design, often used in expressive writing interventions, allows for deeper and continued reflection into specific thoughts and emotions. The prompt will involve reading a vignette that describes the experience and response of a young adult who experiences rejection from a close friend after a first disclosure of their gender identity. Participants will then be asked to write in response to three prompts: 1) identify expressions of internalized transphobia in the vignette character, 2) reflect on times the participant has experienced similar feelings, 3) identify thoughts and feelings that promote and support a positive and affirming identity in contrast to negative emotions and thoughts.

In the IA + Strengthening Social Connections (SSC) Condition, participants will complete the TNB Identity Affirmation intervention on the first three days, following the same prompts as the previous arm. On the fourth day, participants will be directed to compose a brief letter of gratitude to an individual to whom they have not previously expressed gratitude, and who has provided meaningful and affirming support to them as a TNB person. This additional component aims to further enhance social connections and gratitude, which are important factors in promoting well-being.

In the Control Condition, participants will engage in expressive writing about events of the day, without any specific prompts related to TNB identity or social connections. This neutral writing task will serve as a comparison to evaluate the specific impact of the TNB Identity Affirmation and Social Connection interventions on reducing internalized stigma and promoting well-being, compared to general expressive writing.

Exactly! You have successfully designed the study arms. These arms will allow us to assess the impact of TNB Identity Affirmation and Social Connection interventions on reducing stigma and promoting well-being in TNB individuals. Well done!

Ask the client about the next step in the study protocol
Most likely, the next step will be trial design and endpoints. For more information on how to do that, refer to the article on study design.
Review the patient information booklet
Once you're done planning the study arms, make sure the information they'll receive matches the plan. Run through it with a fine-tooth comb to make sure it's medically accurate and covers all the important aspects of each intervention and disease. You don't want to waste time and resources on a trial that has misleading materials. 
Create a consent form
It's good practice to have an independent research team create a consent form and obtain study consent. They'll take the patient through the entire study information, risks, and benefits. Remember, everyone in the research team should have knowledge of the trial and the interventions at a minimum, but preferably deep understanding of both. 
Submit for Institutional Review Board (IRB) approval
Before initiating any study, you need IRB approval. This is a group of physicians and non-physicians who ensure the trial is ethical and will not harm patients. Don't skip this stage. The IRB can and will say no, and it will set the study back if they do. Make sure your protocol, consent form, and all the processes are in order before you submit. 
Start patient screening and enrollment
Once the trial is ready to go, you're ready to start screening the candidates. Make sure to carefully review the inclusion/exclusion criteria. You don't want to waste time on someone who falls out of the study parameters. 
Obtain and review imaging / lab / other data throughout the trial
There will be plenty of data collected throughout the trial. Keep it organized so you can access it quickly when you need it. If you're using a CRO, they'll present you with specific reports they generate and recommendations. 
Conduct quality assurance / quality control (QA/QC) reviews of the data
Every study can always benefit from extra sets of eyes looking over the data to find errors and oddities. Depending on the size and complexity of the study, QA/QC may have full time roles throughout the study or just reviews at specific milestones.

This approach minimizes radiation exposure to healthy surrounding tissues, a hallmark of SBRT.

It utilizes diagnostic quality onboard imaging incorporated within radiation treatment machines. This technology enables the generation and delivery of radiation plans specific to the patient's anatomy at the time of treatment. The goal of this study is to utilize adaptive radiation therapy to deliver ablative radiation with low toxicity rates in a patient population with technically challenging disease.

For the study design, we'll conduct a double-blinded, randomized controlled trial. Subjects will be randomized 1:1 to the intervention or control arm using an online randomization program. Allocation will be stratified by pre-trial smoking status. Patients will be excluded if they have clinical contraindications to heparin therapy. Endpoints will be changes in the severity of smoke-induced inflammation as assessed by the bronchoconstrictor challenge test on day 21 of treatment. Primary analysis will be by an interim analysis of change from baseline in the bronchoconstrictor challenge score. The study hypothesis is that nebulized heparin will decrease smoke-induced inflammation, as assessed by bronchoconstrictor challenge testing, compared to the control arm. To test this hypothesis, we are targeting a sample size of 160 subjects per arm, for a total of 320 subjects total.

Thank you for providing all the necessary information. Based on the details you've given, I would suggest the following study arms:

1. Experimental: Dose Escalation: VVD-130850 Single Agent
   - Participant Group/Arm: Participants receiving ascending doses of VVD-130850 as a single agent.
   - Intervention/Treatment: Participants will take VVD-130850 orally once daily in 21-day treatment cycles during the dose escalation phase.
   - Reasoning: This study arm is necessary to determine the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics, and pharmacodynamics of VVD-130850 as a single agent in participants with advanced solid and hematologic tumors. By escalating the doses, researchers can establish the maximum tolerated dose and assess any potential side effects.

2. Experimental: Dose Escalation: VVD-130850 + Pembrolizumab Combination Therapy
   - Participant Group/Arm: Participants receiving ascending doses of VVD-130850 in combination with pembrolizumab.
   - Intervention/Treatment: Participants will take VVD-130850 orally once daily and receive pembrolizumab intravenously every 3 weeks in 21-day treatment cycles during the dose escalation phase.
   - Reasoning: This study arm is designed to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and potential synergistic effects of combining VVD-130850 with pembrolizumab in participants with advanced solid and hematologic tumors. It aims to determine the optimal dose of the combination therapy for further investigation.

3. Experimental: Dose Expansion: VVD-130850 Single Agent
   - Participant Group/Arm: Participants receiving VVD-130850 at the recommended dose for expansion (RDE) as a single agent.
   - Intervention/Treatment: Participants will take VVD-130850 orally once daily in 21-day treatment cycles during the dose expansion phase.
   - Reasoning: This study arm aims to further evaluate the safety and efficacy of VVD-130850 at the recommended dose determined from the dose escalation phase. It allows for a larger group of participants to receive the drug at the established dose to gather more data on its effects.

4. Experimental: Dose Expansion: VVD-130850 + Pembrolizumab Combination Therapy
   - Participant Group/Arm: Participants receiving VVD-130850 at the recommended dose for expansion (RDE) in combination with pembrolizumab.
   - Intervention/Treatment: Participants will take VVD-130850 orally once daily and receive pembrolizumab intravenously every 3 weeks in 21-day treatment cycles during the dose expansion phase.
   - Reasoning: This study arm is crucial for assessing the safety, tolerability, and potential anti-tumor activity of the combination therapy at the recommended dose for expansion. It allows for a larger cohort of participants to receive the combination treatment and provides more robust data on its efficacy.

   - Rationale: This arm is necessary to test the efficacy and safety of oral microbiota transplant therapy (MTT) in patients with Hidradenitis Suppurativa (HS). By administering lyophilized fecal microbiota capsules derived from a single donor per patient, the researchers aim to alter the gut microbiome and study its effects on the cutaneous microbiota. The dosing regimen of 2 capsules daily for one week followed by one capsule daily for 2 weeks is designed to assess the potential benefits of MTT in improving HS symptoms.

   - Participant Group/Arm: Patients with HS randomized to receive placebo treatment
   - Intervention/Treatment: Drug: Placebo drug
   - Rationale: The inclusion of a placebo group is essential to evaluate the efficacy of the experimental treatment (MTT) in comparison to a control group. By administering a placebo consisting of a mixture of trehalose and crystalline methylcellulose in capsules that are visually indistinguishable from the active product, the researchers can assess the true effects of MTT on HS patients. This arm helps to control for any placebo effects and provides a baseline for comparison with the experimental group.

Study design Considerations by Population
The population you are including to participain the study, or your target population, may be broadly divided into 4 different groups:
Healthy, asymptomatic people who could be the usual care or control group, or the population that is targeted for an intervention
Patients selected to avoid exclusion and are under some treatment or therapy for a particular disease
Healthy volunteers who are treated as control in a placebo controlled study
People who are usually sick who are included in an observational study (the usual care group may also be included in this along with the ones receiving other treatment/or not receiving any).
Please note that the last group may also include a population under observation. For example, all subjects who are being considered for liver transplant.
In a randomised controlled trial(RCT), the target population to be randomised is the group that receives the treatment as well as its control.
The target population to be randomised in a crossover study usually consists of only that group which gets to receive the new treatment first.
For a cohort study, the target population is the entire group/people in which the incidence or prevalence (frequency) of an event has to be estimated.
For a case-control study, the target population could be all people who are diagnosed to have a disease and also the population at risk (i.e. free from disease).

Participants will also receive guidance on physical activity. The training program is inspired by the WHO's recommendations for physical activity. Initially, there will be a 14-day introductory period where the goal is to achieve 30 minutes of moderate-intensity physical activity per day. After 14 days, the patient will receive physiotherapeutic guidance in physical activity and progress to the next period of 14 days, aiming for 2 sessions of 20 minutes of high-intensity physical activity per week. After one month of training, the patient will be guided on maintaining and possibly progressing physical activity. This arm will help us assess the value of early-initiated physiotherapy in improving outcomes for DVT patients.

Yes. Inclusion criteria: -
Participants must be 45 to 65 years old
Participants with atrophic maxillary bone loss greater than 4 mm or less than 7 mm in the mesial and distal dimensions, respectively.
Participants with a healthy supporting bone
Participants without an underlying medical condition that may interfere with the healing process
Participants with adequate mouth opening
Participants without any oral habits that may interfere with the healing process
Participants with a history of trauma or surgery affecting the maxilla
Participants who are willing and able to follow-up
Exclusion criteria: -
Participants with systemic disease that affects bone healing, such as poorly controlled diabetes
Participants with autoimmune diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis
Participants with poorly controlled dentures
Participants with concomitant sinus or dental implant treatment
Participants with poor oral hygiene
Participants who are prone to allergic reactions
Participants who are allergic to any biomedical implant material
Participants who have uncooperative patients or those with psychological problems that may interfere with healing
Participants who have inadequate posterior teeth, severe bone resorption, or TMJ impaction
Participants with dental crowns, bridges, or periodontal disease
Participants with other ongoing procedures affecting the orofacial region

Certainly. In the experimental arm, nulliparous pregnant mothers at term will receive 250 mg IV caffeine and sodium benzoate (125 mg each) dissolved in 500 cc normal saline. This will be administered over the course of two hours upon determination that the patient is 10 cm in cervical dilation. The purpose of this arm is to evaluate the efficacy of caffeine and sodium benzoate in shortening the second stage of labor and augmenting pushing efforts.

In the placebo arm, nulliparous pregnant mothers at term will receive 500 cc normal saline, which will be administered over the course of two hours upon determination that the patient is 10 cm in cervical dilation. The purpose of this arm is to serve as a control group and compare the effects of caffeine and sodium benzoate with a placebo. Below is an example of inclusion and exclusion criteria.
• Patients who are able and willing to provide valid informed consent
• Female or male patients age 18-80
• Patients with a score of 4 or less on the Modified Oxford Score for Humeral Fracture Severity
• Patients with a lengthy acute fracture
• Patients with a spiral and/or oblique fracture or minimal displacement fracture
• Patients who have had open or complex surgery in the last six months
Here in this instance, a screening tool like the Modified Oxford Score can be used to assist in identifying whether the fracture may be severe enough and will require the intervention. Remember, keeping the inclusion and exclusion criteria as narrow as possible will decrease the risk of type I errors but can increase the risk of type II errors.
A recent systematic review by Ramsay and colleagues  evaluated the use of noncompliance of randomized controlled trials with their pre-specified inclusion and exclusion criteria. This systematic review found that 80% of trials have at least 1 significant protocol violation. It is difficult for a researcher to be completely cognizant of all criteria that may be violated during the course of a trial, especially when assessing safety and efficacy of a treatment. Therefore, the authors strongly suggest obtaining independent review of trial protocols before enrolling participants.

Absolutely! Let's go through the reasoning for each arm:

1. For Experimental: Phase 2 - Arm A, we want to assess the efficacy and safety of a higher dose of fianlimab in combination with cemiplimab and chemotherapy. This will help determine the optimal dose of fianlimab for the treatment.

2. In Experimental: Phase 2 - Arm B, we aim to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a lower dose of fianlimab. This will allow us to determine if a lower dose is equally effective with fewer side effects.

3. Experimental: Phase 2 - Arm C serves as a control group to compare the efficacy of cemiplimab and chemotherapy with the addition of a placebo. By including a placebo, we can assess the specific contribution of fianlimab to the treatment outcomes.

4. Experimental: Phase 3 - Arm A or B is designed to confirm the efficacy and safety of the chosen dose of fianlimab in combination with cemiplimab and chemotherapy. Offering two options for the dose of fianlimab allows us to assess which dose is more effective.

5. Finally, Experimental: Phase 3 - Arm C serves as another control group to evaluate the efficacy of cemiplimab and chemotherapy with the addition of a placebo. By including a placebo, we can determine the specific impact of fianlimab on the treatment outcomes.

In Part A - Escalation, we will enroll patients who have either not received systemic therapy for advanced NSCLC or have received at least one line of systemic anticancer therapy for metastatic disease. This arm will help us assess the safety and tolerability of the combination of Tepotinib and Pembrolizumab. We will start with a small number of patients and gradually escalate the dose of Tepotinib to evaluate any potential adverse effects and determine the optimal dosing regimen.

In Part B - Expansion, we will focus on patients with NSCLC and MET exon 14 skipping mutations who have not responded well to previous treatments. This arm aims to evaluate the efficacy of the combination of Tepotinib and Pembrolizumab in a larger group of patients. By targeting patients with specific genetic mutations associated with NSCLC, we can assess the potential benefits of this targeted therapy approach in a population that may have limited treatment options.

In Part A - Escalation, patients will receive Tepotinib daily for three weeks. After three weeks, they will be given Pembrolizumab immunotherapy on a 21-day cycle alongside Tepotinib daily. Dose de-escalation of Tepotinib will be performed if necessary, based on the safety and tolerability assessments.

In Part B - Expansion, patients will receive the combination of Tepotinib and Pembrolizumab throughout the study. The safety run-in of Tepotinib will be tested in the first cycle, followed by the introduction of Pembrolizumab from cycle 2 onwards. This will allow us to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the combination therapy in a larger group of patients with NSCLC and MET exon 14 skipping mutations.

model_response: The drug we’re studying is called ICI201, an engineered T cell that targets proteins produced by the cancer cells. We expect it to induce strong and sustained anti-tumor activity, and we believe that it holds significant potential for improving the outcomes of patients with relapsed/refractory multiple myeloma.

Of course! ICI201 is a CAR-T cell therapy that is created using a patient's own T cells, which are collected from the patient's blood and then engineered in the lab to express a chimeric antigen receptor that redirects the T cells to attack specific myeloma cells. The CAR contains a binding domain that targets GPRC5D, a protein expressed on multiple myeloma cells, and an intracellular signaling domain that activates the T cells to kill themyeloma cells. When the ICI201 CAR-T cells are infused back into the patient, they can immediately begin to attack multiple myeloma cells.
Yes, that is correct.

This personalized approach harnesses the patient's immune system to target and eliminate cancer cells.

groundtruth: Absolutely. The second study arm, labeled as "Drug: Low BPV Regimen," focuses on implementing the low BPV regimen in participants who are in the highest decile of BPV. Each participant's physician will invite them to complete a 48-hour ABPM, followed by cross-titration from their current antihypertensive regimen to the low BPV regimen. The low BPV regimen consists of Amlodipine and Indapamide as the primary medications. I would suggest starting patients on Amlodipine 5mg daily, with uptitration to 10mg daily to achieve a goal systolic blood pressure (SBP) of less than 130 mmHg. Indapamide should be added at 1.25mg daily and increased to 2.5mg daily if needed to meet the target SBP. Other antihypertensive medications should be discontinued as the SBP target is reached. Patients not meeting the target SBP on maximally tolerated Amlodipine and Indapamide will be suggested to have a long-acting angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE)/ angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) added to their therapy. After one week at the target SBP on the low-BPV regimen, patients will complete another 48-hour ABPM for evaluation of the change in BPV.

Participant Group/Arm: Other: Ambulatory Blood Pressure Monitor (ABPM)
Intervention/Treatment: Drug: Low BPV Regimen
Description: Participants on antihypertensive pharmacotherapy in the highest decile of BPV will undergo a 48-hour ABPM to determine baseline BPV. Subsequently, their primary care physicians will be guided through titrations to antihypertensive medications to a low BPV regimen. The optional sub-study will test the hypothesis that ABPM and SKNA data can be simultaneously captured and that BPV will be positively correlated with SKNA. Participants in the sub-study will be fitted with a single patch ECG for the analysis of SKNA.

Patients will be suggested to start with Amlodipine 5mg daily, with uptitration to 10mg daily to achieve a goal SBP of less than 130 mmHg. Indapamide will be suggested to be added at 1.25mg daily and increased to 2.5mg daily, if needed. Other antihypertensive medications will be discontinued as the SBP target is reached. Patients not meeting the target SBP on maximally tolerated Amlodipine and Indapamide will be suggested to have a long-acting ACE/ARB added to their therapy. After one week at the target SBP on the low-BPV regimen, patients will complete another 48-hour ABPM for evaluation of the change in BPV.

How to Determine the Sample Size for Your Clinical Trial Steps 1) Define the key outcomes (or primary, secondary, and tertiary outcomes). 2) Estimate the variability of each outcome based on prior evidence. 3) Identify the necessary sample size for the primary outcome based on power analysis. 4) Allow for a sufficient number of subjects in both arms for multiple subgroup or effect modifier analyses. Remember: The sample size does not only depend on the statistical precision you need but also on the variability you're inherently allowed to observe. Always consider the "intention-to-treat" principle and the lost-to-follow-up principle when planning for the number of subjects in your study. Tips Don't underestimate the size you need for early stopping for futility, and don't overestimate the statistical power you have due to the unknown variability you'll observe. Think about and include all the relevant subgroups and effect modifiers. Sample size calculations also depend on the number of comparisons you wish to make. If you are interested in several outcomes, include enough subjects to analyze those outcomes of interest appropriately - don't run the risk of inadvertently Type II error from underpowering the other outcomes. Don't over-categorize your treatment arms If possible, don't dichotomize. Don't forget to plan for follow up time. Consider drop-outs and treatment discontinuation when doing power calculation considerations. When doing an interim analysis, use a larger sample size to be conservative. Remember, even if you are not looking for superiority, you would need to show non-inferiority. Don't overestimate how long the intervention effect will last. Consider drop-outs, early discontinuation of treatment - always have a sufficient sample size to evaluate these important factors. Considering withdrawals, crossover, lactation, exclusions, interruptions, or changes in treatments along the course of the study. Consider 2 sided testing or multiple hypothesis testing. Always incorporate an a priori plan for multiplicity adjustments into your sample size calculations. Consider an increased sample size for multiple covariates if possible. Consider the fact that many trials don't complete. Don't plan for the worst case scenario - use an average or median scenario Don

First cholecystoscopy will be done 2 weeks after the index procedure.

- Participant Group/Arm: Renal Failure Sleeve Gastrectomy
- Intervention/Treatment: 
   - Diagnostic Test: 6 minutes walk distance
      - Subjects walk as far as possible for 6 minutes at a self-selected pace, and the total distance walked will be recorded
   - Behavioral: Activity Monitor
      - Subjects will wear an Actigraph on their wrist like a watch for up to 10 days at home to monitor activity.
   - Behavioral: Continuous Glucose Monitor
      - Subjects will collect glucose values in the fluid under their skin for up to 10 days at home.
   - Behavioral: Blood Pressure Monitoring
      - Subjects will monitor their blood pressure at home for 10 consecutive days 3 times a day
   - Diagnostic Test: Blood Pressure Monitoring
      - 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure monitoring
   - Diagnostic Test: Body Composition Scan
      - Measure of body fat percentage, skeletal muscle mass, body water, and visceral fat.
   - Diagnostic Test: Mixed meal testing
      - Subjects will consume 6 ml/kg body weight of Boost, up to a maximum of 360 ml, within 5 min
   - Diagnostic Test: Quality of Life
      - Subject will complete Quality of Life Questionnaire

The control group will receive standard of care therapy in addition to adjuvant therapy as prescribed by their personal physician. There will be a 10 minute calibration session with the Motor-cable-driven Rehabilitation Robotic System prior to the start of therapy, and a pre-post exercise assessment of the wrist and forearm is scheduled. Once again, thank you for your time and assistance with designing this clinical trial.

The details are as follows: 1. Motor-cable-driven Rehabilitation Robotic System Arm: Participants will wear the Motor-cable-driven Rehabilitation Robotic System for 30 minutes, three times a week and instructed to perform wrist and forearm rehabilitation exercises. The therapist will also use the system to stimulate the nerve root. The device will continuously monitor the patients progress and the therapist will adjust the resistance of the cable based on the patients feedback. 2. Control Arm: Participants in the control arm will undergo usual care as per standard of care for stroke rehabilitation. In this condition, the therapist will conduct routine treatment for wrist and arm rehabilitation and not use the motor-cable-driven system. Standard of care will follow the current accepted stroke rehabilitation protocols at the site. The control arm is intended to evaluate the treatment efficacy of the novel motor-cable-driven system. 3.1 Are there any anticipated adverse or expected events with this trial? There are no expected serious adverse effects or significant risks with the use of the device. As with any rehabilitation regimen that involves the use of electrotherapy, some minor discomfort or skin burn may occur at the site of contact. With proper use, the risk is minimal however. In some cases of severe or advanced cases of stroke, the risk of rehabilitation may produce a slight risk of muscle strain, sprain, or fracture. 3.2 What precautions will be taken to minimize/mitigate the incidence/severity of the adverse events? The device will be calibrated to ensure that the resistance is set at a safe and tolerable level for each patient, based upon their previous strength. The device has been cleared by the FDA, however, it should only be used under the supervision of a trained professional, and proper precautions should be taken to ensure proper use. Also, any adverse events will be monitored and reported according to current Good Clinical Practice and the FDA's guidelines.
